prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for resenting that my children see their mom as a hero?
My ex wife is a perennial fuck up. She’s been to jail on numerous occasions, had several affairs, lost more jobs than I’ve ever had, and currently lives with her mother. I was a single dad for three years to three children, years where I learned to braid hair so I could care for my daughter. I’ve remarried, and my wife and I provide the children with everything. We pay for their healthcare. We help them with their school work. We sign them up for activities they are interested in and take them to those activities. We pay for those activities. We help them with their school projects. My son is almost 16, and we will buy his car. My eight year old daughter needs braces, and we will pay for them. I ask their mother for no child support because she can’t even support herself. I don’t wish to hurt her. In fact, I’ve forgiven her for who she is and what she’s done. 
Fast forward to tonight: my daughter is entering a pageant. We’ve paid for the dress. We’ve paid the entrance fee. She gets me ask her questions she might be asked at the pageant. One was, “Who is your hero and why?” 
My daughter says, “Do you think I should say, ‘my mom?’”
I said, “ You realize you have family here? We provide for you. We registered you for this pageant. We attended the meeting. You live here full time. We care for you and love you. I know that you get to go to your mom’s every other weekend, and you have no chores there. You eat whatever you like (mom has food stamps), but it’s easy to be a parent two weekends a month. It’s harder to be a parent all the time.” 

I’ve never derogated their mother. I don’t want to cripple their image of her, but it’s frustrating as hell that they see her as this angel and don’t appreciate everything their stepmother and I do for them. 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the person who wrote the story is in the wrong. The situation involves a single dad who's taken care of his kids after a difficult divorce, and now he's upset that the kids see their mom as a hero despite her issues. He's trying to explain to his daughter that the stepmom and he do a lot for her, but the daughter is still considering her biological mom as her hero.

First, I need to consider the dynamics here. The dad is doing a lot for the kids, providing financially and emotionally. The ex is clearly problematic with her history. The dad is frustrated but hasn't directly criticized the mom, just trying to help the daughter understand the support they provide. When the daughter asks if she should say her mom is her hero, the dad points out that the stepmom and he take care of her full-time, while the biological mom only sees them every other weekend. 

Is there something wrong with his approach? He's not saying the mom is bad, just explaining the effort they put in. He's not belittling the mom but trying to balance the daughter's perspective. The key here is whether his response was unfair or harmful. Since he's not attacking the mother directly but highlighting his own and his wife's contributions, it seems reasonable. The daughter is in a position where she's influenced by her time with each parent. The dad's frustration is valid because he's the one providing the majority of care and resources. 

On the other hand, the daughter's admiration for her mom might be because of the less demanding environment. But the dad's response is about making the daughter aware of the support she receives. He's not trying to damage the daughter's relationship with her mom, just expressing his feelings of being undervalued. 

So, is he in the wrong? Probably not. He's addressing the situation honestly without attacking the mother, just emphasizing their sacrifices. The answer should be B (No).
